4.97.text:
With 100's of thousands of calories stored
in their belly, why are fat people hungry?

11.37.text:
Hello everyone, I'm Butter Bob, I lost 150
pounds and made a video about how I did it

17.02.text: called "Butter Makes Your Pants Fall Off",

19.84.text: it's a funny title, but  it's a serious subject about why we fat and what to do about it,

26.40.text: you can watch that here on my Youtube channel.

30.06.text: But, in this video, I'm going to talk about why fat people are hungry

34.12.text: and what they can do to completely control appetite.

38.78.text: Did you know, You could live off the fat you've saved and retire from being hungry all the time?

45.66.text:
The problem is, this huge savings of energy
called "body fat" is locked up.

51.56.text: People who are fat are actually rich in energy,

54.88.text: they have a big fat bank account of stored food, locked up around their belly,

60.04.text: and their butt and chinny, chin, chins.

63.34.text: But, for some reason, they can't make a withdrawal on that account.

68.06.text: It's like the crazy old man who lived on cans of cat food, because he had forgotten about the million dollars he had in the bank.

75.60.text: He was rich, he could have gone to the best restaurant every day and eaten the finest steak with all the trimmings,

83.28.text: but because he forgot he was rich, he lived off cheap cans of cat food.

89.10.text:
This is the problem for most heavy people
too.

92.42.text: They have a huge bank account of stored fat, but they stay hungry all the time.

98.70.text: They have many hundreds of thousands of calories banked away

103.60.text: that could keep them fed and satisfied for a long time,

107.70.text:
yet they can't withdraw this
fortune.

111.52.text: They don't have access to the account number, so to speak,

115.86.text: and without this access, the First National Bank of Belly Fat, will not let them make a withdrawal on their fortune.

124.28.text: Something has stolen their checkbook, something has taken their debit card

129.04.text: and has been using it to steal their food,

131.76.text: while at the same time, preventing them from making a withdrawal from their own account.

137.54.text:
That something is chronically high insulin
levels,

141.96.text: and before you turn me off, stick around and I'll prove what I just said to you in a few minutes.

147.96.text:
This constant high insulin level is like a
identity thief,

152.64.text: it takes your food and locks it away where you can't get to it.

156.94.text: And like an identity thief, as long as it has control, you are locked out of your Bank of Belly Fat account.

165.68.text:
So, if you're fat, you are rich in fat, but
can't use your riches.

172.32.text: At least you haven't been able to use them in the past.

176.48.text:
To explain what I mean a little differently,
let's look at this whole problem from a different angle.

181.94.text: Instead of looking at getting fat, let's look at starvation.

186.78.text: Famous researcher George F. Cahill was a scientist who studied human starvation.

194.22.text: He found out that a 154 pound man (about 70 kilos) had the following energy stored in their body.

204.20.text: They had about 1500 calories of stored sugar or what is called glycogen

210.14.text: stored in their liver and muscles,

212.56.text: which by the way, the body does't like to use, it likes to preserve this energy for emergencies

218.50.text: or for times when food is scarce.

221.16.text: In other words, it likes to hang onto this glycogen.

225.72.text: This average sized person also has about 13 to 15 lbs. (about 6 to 8 kg) of protein,

238.12.text: but Cahill points out that most of the protein is locked up in their tissues and used for processes of living

246.06.text: and very little of it could be used for ready energy.

249.20.text: Besides the body also doesn't like to use protein for energy anyway

254.76.text: and doesn't store extra protein for energy.

259.16.text: Here's the part I really want you to hear me on

262.82.text: Cahill found that the average person, that 154 lb person, that 70 kg person

271.28.text: So, we're not talking about a fat person, we're talking about a fairly trim person

276.10.text:
That 154 lb person had 22 - 33 lbs of
fat (10 to 15 kg of fat) and that trim

284.72.text: and that fairly trim person's fat represented between 100,000 to 150,000 calories of fat.

295.12.text: Cahill estimated that amount of fat was enough energy to keep that fairly trim person alive without eating for between 1 to 3 months.

307.38.text: That's one to three months of a total fast. Total starvation,

312.28.text: living on their own body fat,

314.88.text: Can you imagine if a 154 pound person could live 1 to 3 months on his fat,

322.04.text: how long could I have lived on my fat, when I was 320 pounds?

328.32.text: Here's a couple of pictures of me, to show you what I mean.

334.68.text:
We really don't have to guess too much on
how long a very fat person could live on all that fat,

340.70.text: because there's an actual experiment that was done in the 1960's that gives us an answer.

346.34.text:
A 27 year old Scottish man FASTED for 382
days

353.12.text: (over a year) thirteen months without a bite to eat,

357.66.text: and he lost an astonishing 276 lbs, about 125 kgs.

366.40.text: He was 456 lbs, about 207 kgs and at the end of his fast he was 180 lbs (82 kgs).

376.92.text:
He did this under medical supervision, so
we know he didn't cheat.

381.76.text: You can read all about it in the notes to this video.

384.62.text: The study was called "Features of a successful therapeutic fast of 382 days duration"

392.06.text: This man's 276 lb fat belly amounted to enough fuel to keep him alive for well over a year,

399.94.text: And this 276 lbs of fat, about 125 kg of fat

406.76.text:
would be close to a million calories
of energy.

410.86.text: It's an absolutely amazingly high number.

414.66.text: And you know even more amazing is, to me,

418.28.text: Which means my 150 extra lbs that I lost, was holding at least a half a million calories of energy.

426.84.text: Now here's the question you have to ask yourself? If you think about this,

430.86.text: If 276 lbs of fat is enough energy to keep a man alive for over a year without eating?

438.34.text: Why are fat people ever freaking hungry?

443.70.text:
If that fat belly has all that energy, why
do fat people ever get hungry?

451.06.text:
We can get the answer to that question from
Cahill's work too.

455.42.text: Cahill found that so long as the body is in a fed state,

459.74.text: a state of being where there's food being eaten and insulin levels are high,

465.60.text: then all the tissues, organs and muscles of your body

469.46.text: use blood sugar, made from food for energy and they do not, for the most part, use fat.

476.64.text:
This high insulin level causes the body
to not only store fat, but prevent the releasing of that fat.

486.68.text:
It also prevents the body from using
the stored sugar called glycogen

490.70.text: and prevents the body from using of protein too.

494.04.text:
The body is either burning mostly sugar
from food or what we'll call in a "fed state",

501.68.text:
or burning mostly fat and stored glycogen
and in, what we'll call a "fasted state".

509.98.text: When you eat, you cause your entire body to switch over to burning sugar for several hours.

516.98.text: Sugar made from the food that you eat.

520.28.text: A few hours after you eat, somewhere between 3 hours if you have a normal insulin response,

525.86.text:
longer if you're insulin resistant and even
longer or maybe never if you snack a lot,

532.36.text: the process of storing calories as fat reverses.

537.00.text: First your liver, and your muscles and even your fat cells increasingly switch from using blood sugar from food

544.28.text: to using stored food, or fat, for fuel

549.06.text:
As the insulin levels go down and insulin
doesn't always go down to zero by the way,

554.86.text:
as insulin levels drop and insulin's opposite
hormone glucagon increases, more and more fat is released for fuel.

573.20.text: By 8 to 10 hours after eating, half the energy your muscles are using is coming from fat instead of blood sugar.

581.04.text:
After about 10 hours or so, the levels of fat being released for energy dramatically
increase

587.58.text: as the body increasingly switches to a using fat for energy.

596.54.text: If you only have very limited sugar supplies,

600.34.text: about enough in your blood stream to fuel the body for about one hour according to Cahill,

605.60.text: and if the body likes to hold onto sugar stored as glycogen for an emergency,

611.20.text: and if the body doesn't store extra protein for a rainy day,

615.56.text: and all these things are true, by the way.

618.46.text: but keeps most of it locked up in tissues,

621.72.text: then the only real source of fuel your body has without eating, is body fat.

629.44.text:
Now if that fat is locked up because of high
insulin levels or constant eating, snacking,

636.50.text: then you have to find a way to fuel your body.

639.18.text: In other words, you'll be hungry and tired,

641.88.text:
because even though the body has a tremendous
amount of energy stored in your belly,

649.62.text: So the body tells you to eat, it makes you hungry, to supply it's energy needs.

656.46.text: Cahill found that starvation, or going without food,

661.38.text: is your body's way of switching from using blood sugar made from food, for fuel,

669.70.text: to using body fat for a fuel.

673.56.text: Insulin, or a relative lack of insulin, in relation to it's sister hormone glucagon

679.28.text: depending on whether or not you're feeding or fasting

682.46.text: is the master hormone of this process

686.04.text: and these are George Cahill's words, not Butter Bob Briggs words

690.24.text: Insulin is the master hormone of the fed or fasted state.

695.12.text: If you don't like that, take it up with the works of Mr. Cahill

701.28.text: unfortunately, he has passed away, but he's a published scientist , and some of you critics will have to take that issue up with him.

712.02.text: When you're eating, and it doesn't matter much what you're eating, insulin is higher

718.00.text: and the body is in a FED state.

721.32.text:
While in this FED state, and this lasts for
several hours after you eat, your body, your organs,

727.90.text: your entire body switches to exclusively using blood sugar made from food, or glucose.

736.08.text: Energy being released from fat is greatly reduced or even stopped during this fed state.

742.94.text: Listen, your body is designed to live off FAT in the absence of food.

750.56.text:
You have fat on your body for a number of
reasons, but the most important reason you

755.36.text:
have fat is so you can survive if there was
ever a time when food was scarce.

760.70.text: This is an important point and I want to stress this point.

763.96.text: Your fat is there around your belly as insurance against hard times.

768.64.text: But it can only, ONLY be used in any great amount WHEN YOU ARE DOING WITHOUT FOOD.

776.98.text:
Body fat is there to FEED you when there's
no food.

781.16.text:
Therefore, if you want to get rid of body
fat, you have to do what nature intended you to do,

787.10.text: you have to do without food for periods of time.

790.88.text: And to get this process started, you don't have to go without food for days on end.

795.50.text: The process of switching to fat can be done on a regular basis, daily even. More about that later.

805.70.text:
The fat belly is there to provide us with
food when THERE is NO FOOD.

810.84.text:
It is there to be used when we don't eat or
can't eat.

816.52.text:
The problem for the fat person is this. If
your body doesn't like to burn glycogen when insulin is up,

822.92.text:
and it doesn't like to burn
protein period,

825.50.text: and if higher insulin levels prevent it from releasing belly fat to burn,

830.14.text: and on top of all of these things, if you only have enough blood sugar in your system to fuel your body for about an hour

836.40.text: Where is the body supposed to get energy to continue living?

842.10.text: The answer is really simple, it get's it from food and drink.

847.10.text: That's why the hugely fat person is hungry.

852.04.text: It's a different story for the normal person (normal insulin level),

854.96.text: they have higher insulin for only about 2 hours after eating

859.06.text: and even their higher insulin is still not that high and we'll see that in a minute

865.62.text: as the person who is insulin resistant

868.98.text: During that short window of time, that 2 hours or so,

872.84.text: their body is storing fat too, just like the fat person

876.00.text: But, then that insulin begins to go down

879.66.text: and they start the process of switching over to burning fat, or fasting. Fairly quickly.

885.60.text: And we're going to see something that's going to show that to you in graphic terms in just a second.

891.62.text:
But the insulin resistant person is a different
story.

895.16.text: Their insulin levels go higher and last much longer.

899.82.text: As much as 4 or more hours goes by while they're waiting for these levels to go down.

906.16.text: All this time their body is in fat storage mode.

909.58.text: Their body can't burn glycogen or protein for energy during this time

914.20.text: and the higher insulin levels prevent their body from releasing and burning fat.

919.54.text: Stick with me for a minute and I'm going to show you some amazing graphics that will make all this stuff crystal clear in your mind.

927.58.text:
So their belly is stealing their energy and
leaving them hungry between meals.

932.60.text: Then they do the worst possible thing, they have a snack to make up for this energy loss

939.96.text: and cause their insulin levels to last even longer and grow even higher.

947.30.text: Even some of you on a low carbohydrate diet are doing this too,

952.52.text: you're eating and snacking, thinking the low carb food is the magic of losing weight,

957.86.text: but nothing is further from the truth than this.

961.42.text: Any eating, especially eating lean protein is just keeping you in the higher insulin zone.

969.52.text: You know almost all my videos are about insulin resistance and chronically high insulin levels,

975.30.text: which I call it's, you know, it's travelling partner in crime,

978.96.text:
so in this video, I want you to really see
what this means, so you'll understand.

985.10.text: A picture, or in this case a graph or two is worth a thousand words.

990.66.text: And I want to thank Ivor Cummings,

994.56.text: who by the way has the best video about cholesterol on Youtube entitled "The Cholesterol Conundrum",

1001.02.text: Ivor, put a post about the work of Dr. Joseph Kraft on his Facebook page, and that's how I became aware of Dr. Kraft.

1011.80.text: Dr. Kraft spent 30 years, or more, studying high insulin levels, or what doctors call "hyperinsulinemia"

1020.58.text: in literally 10's of thousands of patients.

1024.86.text:
His work is not theory, he actually blood tested insulin levels in 10's of thousands
of patients

1033.60.text: and recorded the data for decades.

1036.88.text: And this is what we're going to see in a few minutes,

1039.16.text: I have links to his book and an article he wrote in the notes on my website.

1044.74.text: Here's a look at what chronically high insulin levels look like,

1048.54.text: I like the term high insulin level better than insulin resistance,

1053.74.text: because high insulin actually tells you more about your situation than the term insulin resistance.

1065.48.text:
First let's look at a normal person, a person
who doesn't have chronically high insulin levels.

1071.66.text: This person eats, they eat and their insulin goes up like it should.

1077.12.text:
Insulin levels reach their peak at about a
half an hour to an hour after eating,

1084.76.text: But as you'll see when we get to the graphics for people with high insulin levels,

1089.46.text:
even the peak insulin level for these
normal people is small in comparison.

1094.86.text:
By the third hour, their insulin levels have
returned to normal fasting levels.

1101.18.text: And just for reference sake, Dr. Kraft considered insulin between 0 and 30 microunits per ML normal fasting levels,

1110.52.text: and these normal people only doubled that 30 microunit level to about 60 after eating.

1117.74.text: And you're going to see in a few minutes, that people with insulin resistance, their numbers that go MUCH higher.

1125.28.text: So, here's a graphic of the normal insulin pattern

1138.48.text: See, it starts with a fasting level about 8, goes up to about 59, 60 and then starts dropping down by 2 hours

1146.70.text: their back down at the top level of fasting, and by three hours they're back in the fasting level.

1160.20.text: Now let's look at a few people who don't have this normal insulin response:

1164.78.text: This is second one, is what Dr. Kraft calls Pattern 2 or Normal Insulin Peak but a Delayed Return to fasting levels.

1182.38.text:
Insulin levels go higher in these people,
a third higher the first hour

1188.66.text: and double the rate by the first hour after eating.

1192.46.text: But then they are still almost triple the rate of the normal person

1197.84.text: the second hour and don't return to normal until about the fourth hour after eating.

1213.58.text: When we look at this graph, they start out at the fasting level, and hit 93 by the half hour.

1219.68.text: 116 which is almost double what the normal people had by the first hour

1225.84.text: the second hour, they're still 20 points higher than the normal person was during their peak, at the second hour.

1233.48.text: And by the third hour, they're still not down into fasting, the fasting zone.

1245.06.text:
Pattern 3 is what Dr. Kraft calls Delayed
Insulin Peak.

1249.20.text: And this is bad for people who snack after eating, by the way

1254.56.text:
Insulin levels are higher than normal throughout
the hours after eating, but the highest insulin

1261.00.text:
response comes at the second or even third
hour after eating.

1265.06.text:
Normal people would already have their insulin
levels back down into the fasting zone by

1269.64.text:
then, but the people with this pattern 3,
still have very high insulin levels in the

1275.51.text: second and third hour after eating and don't return to normal fasting insulin levels until

1280.87.text:
after the fourth or even fifth hour after
eating.

1284.35.text: And remember, this is Dr. Kraft studying people in a controlled setting, his patients would

1289.42.text: not have been able to grab a snack or a soft drink during those hours after the test began.

1294.78.text:
So if you had this pattern 3 and have a snack,
even a high protein low carbohydrate snack,

1300.93.text:
you're just keeping your insulin levels up
even longer, maybe even for most of the day.

1322.92.text: Pattern 4 is what Dr. Kraft calls High Fasting Insulin.

1327.20.text: Now these are the people who even before they eat,

1332.46.text: have insulin levels almost as high as the normal person does even after they've eaten.

1338.54.text:
If you'll notice, the other patterns had a
fasting insulin level of between 0 and 30 microunits/ml.

1347.64.text: But these poor unfortunate people have fasting insulin levels above 50, this is BEFORE they ate.

1361.02.text: Just to put this, these people into perspective

1364.16.text:
Normal people, after they eat, their insulin
goes to a peak of 60

1368.98.text: But these people maintain a level of 50 even in the fasted state.

1374.74.text:
I would guess these people would be people
who would find it almost impossible to lose

1379.23.text:
weight without finding a way to reduce that
fasting level.

1383.22.text:
Worst than that, when they eat their levels
stay up triple the normal level of insulin

1388.86.text: for 4 hours and never completely go to normal fasting levels even after 5 hours after eating.

1404.00.text: Here's a graphic with the normal insulin response in light blue and the three patterns of high

1409.87.text: insulin all together above it in yellow, orange and green.

1421.64.text: The most interesting thing to remember from Dr. Kraft's graphics is this:

1426.84.text: Two people sit down to eat a meal, one might have a normal insulin response to that meal

1432.14.text:
that will leave them back to normal fasting
insulin levels in 3 hours.

1436.98.text: And they won't get a very high insulin level even after they eat.

1441.34.text: The other one might have higher insulin levels BEFORE they even start eating

1446.28.text: and after they eat, their insulin numbers might be as high as three times the amount as their normal

1452.11.text:
eating partner and they might not be back
at normal fasting levels for 5 hours or more.

1458.49.text:
Some of them, because they remain hungry even
after eating because of this high insulin

1464.18.text:
response, will snack, these people will almost
never be at normal fasting insulin levels.

1471.42.text:
One important note, Dr. Kraft tested the low
carbohydrate diet and found that it can change

1476.88.text:
these abnormally high insulin patterns to
a normal insulin pattern within a years time.

1483.05.text: I'll link to his study in my notes.

1485.70.text:
So, from scientist George Cahill's many works,
we learn that the body only releases fat when

1491.50.text:
we don't eat and insulin is low, otherwise
the body remains in the fed state and uses

1496.77.text: blood sugar from food as it's energy source.

1500.35.text:
From Dr. Joseph Kraft's work, we learn that
some people release a lot more insulin than

1505.91.text:
normal and this insulin lasts MUCH longer
than normal.

1511.48.text:
Cahill tells us that this high insulin causes
them to not be able to use their stored glycogen,

1517.15.text: or stored sugar, and keeps them from burning protein, which the body doesn't like to burn

1522.16.text:
anyway and most importantly of all, keeps
them from burning their body fat for fuel

1526.90.text: for hours and hours. Leaving them with about an hours worth of sugar that they have in

1534.65.text: In other words, leaving them hungry for energy and looking for something to eat to supply that energy.

1540.07.text: So they eat a snack and make this whole rotten vicious cycle last even longer.

1545.36.text: Because if you eat, you raise insulin levels all over again.

1550.84.text: What can you do about this?

1554.36.text: Fat, your body fat is there around your middle, because your body thinks it is in a fed state all the time.

1561.78.text:
And if your insulin pattern
is like these we've looked at, you probably

1566.09.text:
are in that fed state most of the hours of
the day, everyday.

1570.20.text:
There's only one way, there's only one way,
one way of getting this fat off, if the body

1577.30.text:
believes that fat needs to be stored and held
onto because there's plenty of food, and it

1583.48.text:
does believe this if insulin remains high,
then it is waiting for something.

1591.16.text: It's waiting for the signal that food is not available, that's what it's waiting for.

1599.92.text: Low insulin levels is that signal.

1604.82.text: As soon as you give it that signal, that food is not available,

1608.88.text: it will start releasing the fat. It just will,

1612.34.text: the work of George Cahill has shown us that.

1615.10.text: That's why so many different diets work, any

1618.29.text:
diet that restricts your calories, makes your
calories really low, therefore lowing your

1623.30.text:
insulin levels, is going to send that signal,
because it lowers your insulin level and this

1628.67.text: sends the signal to release the fat.

1631.23.text: The problem is sustainability, in a world

1633.83.text: where food is everywhere, it's hard to sustain a low calorie diet.

1639.13.text: Is it impossible? No. People have done it, many people have done it.

1644.48.text: but a Low Carb, High Fat diet, the diet I used to lose 150 pounds is a diet hack,

1651.55.text: it's a trick. It's an imitation of fasting, an imitation of starvation. Starvation itself is a situation

1658.50.text:
where circulating fat is high and insulin
is low, a LCHF diet is also a situation where

1665.91.text:
circulating fat is high and insulin is lower.
So what's the trick? We are restricting carbs,

1673.73.text:
and we're keeping our protein fairly low,
not low enough to make us sick, and destroy our muscles,

1678.97.text: but low, because protein has an effect on insulin that is about half that of carbs.

1685.02.text: That's right, when you eat protein, especially some low fat, lean protein, you are actually raising your insulin

1693.01.text: about half as much as eating carbohydrates.

1696.15.text: We feed our body fat for a reason,

1698.67.text: firstly, so we can have something to eat, which makes this diet sustainable.

1703.74.text: You know trying to go without food long enough to make a difference is extremely hard to do.

1708.86.text: But this way of eating allows you to eat.

1711.98.text: This sustainable fat diet allows us to eat, which makes the diet easy

1716.46.text: and the high fat part of this diet sends the signal to the body that we're not eating,

1722.28.text: you see it's a trick, because if the body has a lot of fat circulating around inside, fat from the diet,

1728.74.text: the body thinks it's in starvation mode already,

1732.44.text: because if it was actually going without food, the body itself would be releasing fat.

1738.58.text: So if we eat fat, when we do eat, it's sending the SAME signal that the body would get if

1745.30.text: it was actually going without food.

1748.14.text: Fat is also the food with the LEAST effect on insulin,

1751.68.text: so insulin is kept low by the fatty food

1755.12.text: and the very fact that fat is in the system at a higher level,

1759.18.text: and insulin is low, sends the body the signal that it's not eating.

1764.30.text: You see to the body, it's all the same,

1766.70.text:
if you are actually starving, insulin is low
and the body is releasing fat from your belly,

1771.16.text: so the levels of circulating fat are higher.

1774.04.text: Eating a LCHF meal in essence tricks the body into believing that food is scarce

1781.44.text: because insulin is low and there's fat in the system.

1783.86.text:
So this LCHF diet trick makes this diet sustainable,
because we can eat during eating times, and

1791.08.text:
here's the trick, you need to find a way to
not eat and this is the way.

1795.72.text:
This is the way to not eat, because when we
eat a high fat, low carb and a very moderate

1802.61.text:
protein diet, it kills our appetite. BTW,
even George Cahill tells us in his work that

1809.10.text:
you only need about 15% of your calories as
protein. These people telling you that if

1814.55.text:
you eat fat it will prevent you from losing
body fat are just plain wrong. Fat controls

1821.10.text:
the appetite because it controls insulin,
but protein has half the effect on insulin

1828.14.text:
as carbs. And therefore, if the appetite is
controlled by the relatively small amount

1833.94.text:
of fat we are eating - calorie wise, then
we can go long periods without food, because

1840.54.text: our body will make up the difference by releasing our stored fat from our belly.

1845.83.text:
Look, when I say eat a high fat diet, I'm
not talking about eating a high calorie diet.

1852.04.text: I'm not talking about eating sticks of butter. I'm talking about eating a high percentage

1857.48.text:
of the lower calorie diet that you will be
eating as fat. A high fat percentage meal

1864.88.text:
or two, not a high calorie diet. And you don't
have to worry about your calories that much,

1870.75.text:
just eat low-carb high fat, moderate protein
until you're satisfied, then listen to the appetite

1879.09.text:
control that diet will give you and don't
eat when not hungry. You'll end up eating

1884.97.text: a lower calorie diet without effort or thought. Now listen, this is the trick, the not eating,

1892.38.text:
not eating, the fasting, intermittent fasting,
the going without food is what the body has

1900.69.text:
been waiting for, it is the signal that tells
it to get rid of the fat.

1906.72.text:
Because looking for a time when we're not
eating is the whole reason it stored fat in

1910.95.text: the first place. This fat around your belly and your

1915.87.text:
butt and chinny chin chins is there and it's
been there waiting for you to NOT EAT.

1922.45.text: And this diet makes it simple to NOT EAT.
